title: 109_hr5924
content: PRIVATE DISASTER LOANS. Private Disaster Loans: Definitions include 'disaster area' as a declared county, parish, or similar unit of government, and 'eligible small business concern' as a small business defined by the Small Business Act or the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. The Administrator may guarantee timely payment of all principal and interest on loans issued by qualified private lenders to eligible small businesses in disaster areas within a 24-month period. These loans can be used for any purpose authorized under subsection (a) or (b). The Administrator can establish an online application process for loans guaranteed under this subsection and coordinate with other federal agencies for assistance. The online application process for disaster relief assistance allows applicants to specify a qualified private lender for obtaining a loan. If no lender is specified, any qualified private lender may be selected. The Administrator may determine a means of distributing applications to private lenders if not specified by the applicant. Loans guaranteed under this subsection can be used for refinancing debt under certain acts. The Administrator has the authority to determine guarantee percentages. The Administrator may guarantee up to 85% of a loan with a maximum amount of $3,000,000. The longest term for a loan without collateral is 15 years, and with collateral is 25 years. No guarantee fee is collected, but an origination fee is paid to qualified private lenders. The Administrator may guarantee up to 85% of a loan with a maximum amount of $3,000,000. A qualified private lender can charge an origination fee equal to 0.15% of the loan amount. The lender can use its own loan documentation, and the Administrator will establish criteria for lenders within 30 days of enactment. The Administrator will establish regulations for qualified private lenders within 90 days of enactment. Banks and lending institutions meeting the criteria can continue as qualified private lenders. The Small Business Administration will provide assistance to small businesses without preventing them from receiving other aid under the Act. Appropriations will be made available to carry out this subsection, including the authority to reduce interest rates by up to 3 percentage points. The amendments made by this section apply to disasters declared under the Small Business Act before, on, or after the date of enactment. For disasters declared before the enactment date, the 24-month period for assistance begins on the declaration date. SEC. 2. TECHNICAL AND CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. The Small Business Act is amended in sections 4(c) and 7(b) to update references and provisions related to loan interest rates. The Small Business Act is amended to update loan interest rate provisions. The interest rate on the Administration's share of any loan made under subsection (b) is specified.
